prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAM04191
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observing IRAM04191 which was shown to be devoid of a large disk from our CALYPSO observations: testing the kinematics of the inner envelope down to scales where if no disk is present, angular momentum should present clues of magnetic braking. This is the lowest luminosity source of the sample, and is essential to probe disk formation and angular momentum distribution in protostars of different luminosities.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We want to resolve lines which are 3-5 km/s wide (especially C17O, C34S and H13CO+), with at least 5 channels so as to be able to build position-velocity diagrams and disentangle between different radial velocity profiles. To do so a 0.1-0.2 km/s velocity channel is needed.

We need to test the presence of protostellar disks and or magnetic braking signatures at 20 AU radii: 0.11" for Perseus and 0.17" for Taurus. We also want to recover the emission up to 4" so as to have enough baseline overlap with our PdBI dataset and carry out joint analysis of the kinematics (N2H+, C18O, C17O) at all sacles in the envelope.

Our requested sensitivity is driven by the detection of the C17O line to be able to analyze teh envelope kinematics at scales 20 AU. The C17O(3-2) line strength is estimated from our C18O(2-1) PdBI observations at 0.7" resolution.
From our CALYPSO observations of C18O(21), we first estimate the C18O(3-2) line strength, by using RADEX with a kinetic temperature 20 K and typical densities as measured from our CALYPSO data: C18O(21) and C18O(32) are expected to have similar peak fluxes in these conditions. We then use an isopopical ratio [C18O/C17O]4 measured in Taurus (Ladd 2004) to downscale the C18O(3-2) emission to C17O(3-2) expected strength. Finally, assuming that the CO emission follows a brightness radial distribution from the protostellar envelope emission we obtain the expected C17O(3-2) line peak in the ALMA beam. However, the C18O emission is optically thick at our CALYPSO resolution: for each source we extrapolate a Gaussian profile from the C$^{18}$O(2--1) wings, downscale the profile by 4, we expect a C$^{17}$O(3--2) peak to be 1.5 to 2 times stronger than the value extrapolated from optically-thick line peak, in a 0.17$\arcsec$ ALMA beam. We also consider that 60\% of the line intensity is contained in the 7 central hyperfine components in 0.3km/s. Doing that for each of our 8 sources, we expect C$^{17}$O(3--2) lines to be >25 mJy/beam for IRAM04191, and >70 mJy/beam for the Perseus sources Bandwidth for the sensitivity: At a radius of 20 AU, the Keplerian speed in the lowest-mass protostar of our sample, IRAM04191 is expected to be $v = (GM/r)^{0.5} = 1.5$ km s$^{-1}$.
To detect the signature of keplerian rotation in the C$^{17}$O line wings, we therefore request a sensitivity 3 mJy/beam in a 0.25 km s$^{-1}$ channel for IRAM04191, and 12 mJy/beam in a 0.25 km s1 channel for the Perseus sources.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Perseus sources
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observing 7 Perseus sources from our CALYPSO sample. These sources are devoid of a large (>60 AU in radius) disk from our CALYPSO observations: we aim to test the kinematics of their inner envelopes down to scales where, if no disk is present, angular momentum should present clues of magnetic braking.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We want to resolve lines which are 3-5 km/s wide (especially C17O, C34S and H13CO+), with at least 5 channels so as to be able to build position-velocity diagrams and disentangle between different radial velocity profiles. To do so a 0.1-0.2 km/s velocity channel is needed.

We need to test the presence of protostellar disks and or magnetic braking signatures at 20 AU radii: 0.11" for Perseus and 0.17" for Taurus. We also want to recover the emission up to 4" so as to have enough baseline overlap with our PdBI dataset and carry out joint analysis of the kinematics (N2H+, C18O, C17O) at all sacles in the envelope.

Our requested sensitivity is driven by the detection of the C17O line to be able to analyze teh envelope kinematics at scales 20 AU. The C17O(3-2) line strength is estimated from our C18O(2-1) PdBI observations at 0.7" resolution.
From our CALYPSO observations of C18O(21), we first estimate the C18O(3-2) line strength, by using RADEX with a kinetic temperature 20 K and typical densities as measured from our CALYPSO data: C18O(21) and C18O(32) are expected to have similar peak fluxes in these conditions. We then use an isopopical ratio [C18O/C17O]4 measured in Taurus (Ladd 2004) to downscale the C18O(3-2) emission to C17O(3-2) expected strength. Finally, assuming that the CO emission follows a brightness radial distribution from the protostellar envelope emission we obtain the expected C17O(3-2) line peak in the ALMA beam. However, the C18O emission is optically thick at our CALYPSO resolution: for each source we extrapolate a Gaussian profile from the C$^{18}$O(2--1) wings, downscale the profile by 4, we expect a C$^{17}$O(3--2) peak to be 1.5 to 2 times stronger than the value extrapolated from optically-thick line peak, in a 0.17$\arcsec$ ALMA beam. We also consider that 60\% of the line intensity is contained in the 7 central hyperfine components in 0.3km/s. Doing that for each of our 8 sources, we expect C$^{17}$O(3--2) lines to be >25 mJy/beam for IRAM04191, and >70 mJy/beam for the Perseus sources Bandwidth for the sensitivity: At a radius of 20 AU, the Keplerian speed in the lowest-mass protostar of our sample, IRAM04191 is expected to be $v = (GM/r)^{0.5} = 1.5$ km s$^{-1}$.
To detect the signature of keplerian rotation in the C$^{17}$O line wings, we therefore request a sensitivity 3 mJy/beam in a 0.25 km s$^{-1}$ channel for IRAM04191, and 12 mJy/beam in a 0.25 km s1 channel for the Perseus sources.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: While large circumstellar disks are observed around young stars, only 3 large (r>100AU) candidate keplerian accretion disks have been suggested around young (Class 0) protostars so far. Our recent results with the PdBI CALYPSO survey confirmed the extreme paucity of large disks around Class 0 protostars, challenging the long-standing picture of disk formation as a natural result of angular momentum conservation during the collapse of rotating cores. MHD simulations suggest that magnetic fields can redistribute angular momentum via magnetic braking during the main accretion phase, and delay the formation of large disks. We propose to observe a sample of 8 of the youngest low-mass Class 0 protostar, already well-characterized at scales >100 AU thanks to our CALYPSO survey dataset. These 8 protostars have a wide range of luminosities, and are all devoid of large-scale disks, making them good candidates for magnetized protostellar collapse. Our ALMA observations will characterize the angular momentum distribution at scales 20-500 AU, where we should either find disks, or where magnetix braking must be efficient.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
